functionalNotes:
The RMS database has CDC enabled, which involves the addition of a new schema (14, cdc), a new filegroup, and a new file.  Consequences of the enabling of CDC are that two new jobs are added to SQL Server Agent per RMS database with CDC enabled (capture and cleanup), and a new user (cdc) is added to the database.  These jobs and the new user should be left untouched.

Where management of databases does not use the master spts provided by DT, or they are not kept up to date, consideration should be given as to what changes are necessary for CDC integrity to be retained.
developerNotes:
Implementation of CDC
What is it?
At this point it is the putting in place of the components needed to implement cdc tracking on tables.  It does not itself add cdc tracking.
It can be considered the equivalent of adding the BI database without adding BI processing.
It is invisible to the client, it does nothing.  Except where the client looks after the databases themselves.

What does the update do?
It enables CDC on the RMS database, creates a new filegroup, creates a new file, adds the filegroup to the file.
SQL Server does some changes to support this:
It adds a new schema, cdc (schema_id = 14).  (We must limit our queries of system tables to the dbo schema (schema_id = 1), we never bothered because we never had cause.  This update includes some amendments to that effect.)
It adds a new user, cdc.
It adds two new scheduled jobs, capture and cleanup, in the cdc schema.  These are executed by the cdc user.  Removing the cdc user causes the cleanup job to error.  Don't do that.

It adds new spt stored procedures:
spt_EnableCDCForAnRMSDatabase - the procedure that enables cdc on the RMS database, creates a new filegroup, creates a new file, adds the filegroup to the file
spt_SetCDCTrackingForATable - sets (or unsets) CDC tracking for a table, runs spt_CreateCDCTrigger and spt_EnableOrDisableRMSBITriggersForATable
spt_SetCDCTrackingForAllTablesWithABITrigger - runs spt_SetCDCTrackingForATable for all tables with a BI trigger
spt_CreateCDCTrigger - takes the BI trigger on the RMS table as a template, makes changes to make it suitable for the BI table, and applies it to the BI table
spt_EnableOrDisableRMSBITriggersForATable - enables or disables the RMS BI trigger(s) on a table

It updates the RMS spt procedures that change the schema.
spt_AddColumnToTable
spt_AlterColumnOnTable
spt_RemoveColumnFromTable
spt_Rename_Column
When called, these do additional things where the RMS table has cdc tracking enabled.  It disables then enables tracking.

It updates the RMS spt procedure that deletes and reseeds a table
spt_DeleteAndReseed
A table that has cdc tracking enabled cannot have TRUNCATE TABLE run against it.  This test is added to the existing test for a FK reference. 

It updates all existing BI triggers to include new standard code that exits the trigger, doing nothing, if the table has cdc tracking enabled (except when integration tests are being run).  Note that the intent is that the RMS BI trigger would also be disabled when cdc tracking is enabled.

**Any overrides of standard Iho triggers, and any new client-specific BI triggers should have that standard code added, as soon as possible.**
title: CDC Trigger Implementation

developerNotes:
A new system constant has been added "SMTPEnableSSL". This boolean system constant defaults to false, which is the behavior of Iho previously. 
For any client implementations that need to send email via SMTP with SSL, setting this system constant to true will allow emails to be sent without receiving an error. An example would be when emails are being sent using Exchange Online's High Volume Email, which requires SSL.
title: smtp.EnableSsl = systemConstantRepository.GetBoolean("SMTPEnableSSL", false);

functionalNotes: Change to spf_CalculatePenaltyOpeningAmounts to correctly identify a refund.
developerNotes:
Incorrectly processed refund GL records (identifiable by the incorrect RelatedTransactionTypeID, it should be 5, it is 2 where this problem has occurred) are recorded in a table called TFS257637Output.  These records are updated with the correct values in RelatedTransactionTypeID and RelatedTransactionID.
The retention of TFS257637Output allows further investigation of potentially incorrect GeneralLedgerRevenueAccount records, which is outside the scope of this bugfix.

Note that one consequence of this fix and data correction is that an over-refund now results in penalties.  This would be a situation where a credit return is refunded, then assessed to a smaller credit, leaving a debit balance.
title: spf_ProcessPenalty inserting into PaymentTransactionBreakdown

functionalNotes: A disclaimer pops up when it has been configured by the client re Tax Types. The modifiers are working as per the AC for FP23.
developerNotes:
Added functionality to configure a single disclaimer per tax type, and have it display when custom date calculation ('o') applies.
For a disclaimer to appear:
1. The tax type must be either 'adhoc' or 'adhoc-multiple'
2. The DisclaimerText column on the TaxType table must contain a value
3. The tax type must be associated with at least one active TaxTypeDays table entry with 'o' as the modifier. This can be any/all of ReturnDueModifier, PaymentModifier, and GraceModifier
title: Display disclaimer text based on tax type configuration

VERY IMPORTANT:
To be able to view the Multiple Ad hoc return number in the period (i.e show 15 July (#1)) in Tax Accounts and Returns list page, project will need to empty OnlineReturn_AdhocPeriodDateFormat system constant value
i.e.
EXEC spf_SystemConstant_set
    @Name          = 'OnlineReturn_AdhocPeriodDateFormat',
    @ConstantValue = '';
Reason is the current behaviour is to show the Ad hoc Period in the format of OnlineReturn_AdhocPeriodDateFormat which is set to dd MMM.

functionalNotes: To configure the auto credit transfer behaviours based on return frequencies for the same tax type for both of push and pull.
developerNotes:
New column (ReturnFrequencyID) added to TaxTypeAutoCreditTransferConfiguration, and made part of the primary key (was TaxTypeID, now TaxTypeID / ReturnFrequencyID).
(This field is NOT nullable, there is no NULL value that could cover all return frequencies without a specific record, a catchall, as this would remove the ability to not have ACT for a return frequency.  If a return frequency does not support ACT, this is indicated by no active record on TaxTypeAutoCreditTransferConfiguration.)
As part of the upgrade all existing configuration for a tax type has been applied to all return frequencies valid for that tax type.
The TaxType worksheet and json files have had the ACT configuration removed.  TaxTypeAutoCreditTransferConfiguration has its own json file, and its own worksheet in the TaxType spreadsheet, thus enabling multiple sets of data per tax type.
The derivation of the appropriate ACT configuration depends on the return frequency of the period being processed.  It is not expected that taxpayers will be changing return frequencies for a registration.
Once the configuration has been found, the subsequent functionality is unchanged.

Note that these changes will require changes to the clients' spreadsheets and / or json (depending on what's being used) to match the new templates.
title: See User Story - Configure max transfer period per tax type return frequency

functionalNotes:
A period has a credit balance, it comprises a credit return and a payment.  This credit balance is available for a REF case, and a Refund record is created for the total balance.  Subject to configuration, this refund is eligible for credit interest to apply "after some time".  Once this time has passed, credit interest applies only to the core tax amount of the refund.  This is default Iho functionality.

There's a new system constant, RefundInterestAmountMode, which supports two values:
'CoreTaxOnly' is the default, and is current Iho funtionality
'ApprovedRefund' takes the amount remaining on the Refund record
developerNotes:
Added in a new system constant, and used its value to determine which method is used to find the amount against which interest applies.

Note that spf_CalculateRefundInterest has been updated.  This will be a breaking change for Cyprus.
"Any changes made in this proc need to be applied into override Cyprus proc (spf_CalculateRefundInterest) as well."
title: Credit interest configuration option

functionalNotes:
Three tables have been added to Non-Individual Income Tax return:
Fixed Assets Table UI (to be used for CIT/PIT in Cyprus)
Table with subtotals (to be used for CIT/PIT in Cyprus) 
Table with various data types (an example of different data types that can used within Iho v3)

The tables function correctly through Filing and Amending a return, display correctly in Submit & Review page and View Return page, and maps correctly into the Back office.
developerNotes:
This is based on details in the Table Entry Requirements document (See ticket Links)

Purpose
This will extend tax return entry for detail questions to support 'table based' entry. This is additional to the current 'row by row' entry.
Table based entry refers a defined set of rows and columns being preloaded and presented in a table structure.  Rows are fixed and cannot be added or removed
Image

Features
Each column is configured using the normal detail question configuration
A single flag at the question level switches to the new mode (set TaxReturnQuestion.ShowTable to true)
There are many advanced features 

Configuration
All standard detail question configuration is supported
The only fixed requirement for the detail questions is that the first row must be a lookup. The items in this are displayed as the labels for each row. It is expected thger code tables will be used
Each codes items can have a prefix to control formatting and add features. Examples include Header Rows, hiding individual cells and column level subtotals using specified columns (as apposed to the normal row based calculations
Prefix tags are double square brakets [[ ]] and require json inside except fpr headings that must just have HEAD

Saving
No changes here, these are saved as normal detail questions
title: Cyprus - CiT / PiT Online UI Design Changes

Update all instances of GETDATE() (and equivalent) in db procs / functions etc to use fGetCurrentDate() / fGetCurrentDateUtc() so they are compatible with time shifting. Add TestNoObjectDefinitionsUsingDefaultSqlDate test to detect future instances of default sql dates to ensure these aren't re-introduced. Add fGetCurrentDateUtc() function to support current UTC date.

To the regions - We want to follow this standard in the client layers as well so a unit test should be added in the client layer which calls DataTorque.Iho.UnitTestFramework.FrameworkTests.TestNoObjectDefinitionsUsingDefaultSqlDate(). This test will inform of all instances of GETDATE() (and equivalent) in the client database and these should be replaced with fGetCurrentDate() / fGetCurrentDateUtc()

developerNotes:
The PaymentBankAssetAccountID value should match the AccountID of the Account that represents "Here is where we record actual cash received into RMS". For most, this will be the same AccountID that is saved to the system constant "ac_Cash".

Previously, there was code that looked for this value as the default, but it searched using the account "code" value. This value is not guaranteed to be the same across all clients. So, we've changed the code to use the battle-tested system constant "ac_Cash".

This default value will only be used if no other account can be found through the BankAssetAccountMapping table.
title: Hard coded account code in TaxpayerAccountRepository -> GetPaymentBankAssetAccountID causing issues

developerNotes:
When displaying Return Detail Answers of type percent online, if the selected culture uses a comma as the decimal separator, the JS function DTCore.js TryParseFlaot() used to parse the JSON value, failed to recognise it as a valid number. This is fixed by replacing "," with "." in this function.
Note that javascript does not natively support a thousand separator, nor any char other than "." as the decimal separator, including when the OS / Browser culture does.
Going forward, developers should try to use an alternative function to this that takes in the current culture when trying to parse a numeric value from a string depending on the source of the value.

functionalNotes: Account Adjustments now trigger the auto credit transfer process.
developerNotes:
Account adjustments have an effect on the amount that can be transferred automatically, although they do not directly contribute to the amount available for transfer.
A debit account adjustment will increase the debt in a period and therefore decrease the available credit.
A credit account adjustment will decrease the debt in a period and therefore increase the available credit.

Processing an account adjustment did not correctly reverse / apply auto credit transfers.  The ACT methodology has been refactored to do this without changing the behaviour elsewhere.

Clients will now see accounts affected when an account adjustment occurs in a period within an auto credit transfer chain.
title: Auto Credit Transfer - Amend the period where trigger FinalAction makes transferred credits reversed

To find if you need changes, the easiest thing to is search your web project for moment(

key step
search for moment.js - replace with luxon.js
search for moment( and replace with helper methods in dtcore.js
--> toLuxonDate  -- used for date with out format
--> parseLuxonDateWithFormat used for dates with formats


Most common upgrade path
The most common upgrade path will just be replacing moment.js with luxon.js in any checked in files in the solution
Other migration steps would only be needed if the website has custom files with custom date handling. That shouldnt be many projects.

Multiple sources of automatic credit transfers are available for configuration.  There is no UserInterface for this, it is not something that clients should change.

Spreadsheet / json configuration changes are supported.
developerNotes:
The flag IsOriginACreditReturn on CreditTransferChain is no longer sufficient.  It is necessary to support other (configurable) sources of automatic credit transfers.

There is a new standard lookup table, CreditTransferChainOrigin, that holds the allowed sources, whether they are eligible, and the order in which they are processed if on the same effective date.

Iho defaults to only Credit Return, Manual Credit Transfer, and Credit Account Adjustment being eligible.

Source transactions are handled and transferred individually, within their own chains, and follow the same rules.
title: Auto Credit Transfer enhancement - multiple configurable sources - #1 - schema changes

functionalNotes:

Note that the flag CannotHaveAnAuditCase on TaxTypeAutoCreditTransferConfiguration has been extended to also apply to Objection and Appeal cases.  It already applied to Audit and Assessment cases.
developerNotes:
Implementation of the schema changes in 264423 for Push, including prevention of Pull erroring if picked up prior to completion of 264425 or 264426, as applicable.

Now tests for more sources of credit if so configured, processing them in the correct order.

Note that:
Account Adjustment processing had to be amended to do penalties and post-penalty procedures after the AA was created.
Credit Transfer processing had to be amended to do penalties and post-penalty procedures after the CT was updated with the General Ledger Transaction ID.

functionalNotes:
To restate the purpose of this change.  Some case types prevent a credit in a period within the scope of the case from being automatically transferred.  Once the case is closed, credits are available and should be processed without waiting for the next financial interaction.

Case closure is considered too late, instead it should be at the point of unlocking the period, if the case type is one which locks the period (DBT is an example of a case type that does not).  Case Types that do not lock the period must wait until closure, there is no other indicator that the case is not a blocker for auto credit transfer.

Unlocking a period within a case will trigger auto credit transfer, but only if:
    Credit transfers are configured for the tax type / return frequency
    At least one of the configuration flags CannotHaveAnAuditCase or CannotHaveARefundCase are set to 1
    The locking reason for the tax return included a Case Type abbreviation for a case type that a flag of 1 refers to

Closing a case will trigger auto credit transfers for all periods within the scope of the case, but only if:
    Credit transfers are configured for the tax type / return frequency
        The configuration flag CannotHaveADebtCase is set to 1, and
        The case type is one that the flag of 1 refers to, i.e. DBT, or

        The configuration flag CannotHaveUnpresentedRefund is set to 1, and
        The case type is one that the flag of 1 refers to, i.e. RFD, and
        The Refund record has no amount left to disburse
developerNotes:
The processing order of cases is not what might be expected.  Consider an Audit case.  Taxpayer Account Changes are made, submitted for approval, approved, and Save and Continue clicked.  At this point the tax return and general ledger tables are updated, penalties recalculated.  Auto credit transfer won't happen, because the case is open and the return is locked.  Once the return is unlocked, it will attempt to process auto credit transfer, but when is the tax return unlocked?

The expectation is that it's at this point, when the changes have been saved.  That turns out not to be the case.  It's not until the case is closed.  The Case is set to Closed, periods within scope are unlocked, the spf_ProcessTaxReturnCaseClosedRules procedure is run.  That's what happens whether the case is closed normally, by optional closure, or by deletion.

Putting the changes in the unlock procedure instead of the case closed procedure makes no difference.  It has been done anyway in case one day unlocking is moved, a decision outside the scope of this change.
title: Auto Credit Transfer enhancement - multiple configurable sources - #5 - post case changes

developerNotes: PAY 001 (Payments Received Management) gets its data from the BI DB while PAY 010 (Payment Listing) queries the transactional DB.  While some changes can be made to the SQL so that the selection logic matches, issues with the data migration or data can mean that the data sets are different. functionalNotes: When a taxpayer has Browse>Returns screen open, and one of the listed returns is amended via the website (whilst the Browse>returns is open on screen), and then the amended return has the report printed from this screen, it should show the correct assessment data.
developerNotes:
The action to print this report comes from IhoUserInterface\UserControls\TaxReturnBrowseController.cs:PrintReturn().
This method passes the value for the report stored procedure parameter '@TaxReturnID' from 'currentRow.ID'.

So, if an assessment has occurred, it is possible that a new tax return record has been created under the same TaxReturnHeader record as the latest version. That would mean that the value for 'currentRow.ID' is invalid. Likely made inactive which is why the report is blank.

The solution was to make the report stored procedure check if there was a new active tax return under the associated tax return header record.

functionalNotes:
To restate the purpose of this change.  Some case types prevent a credit in a period within the scope of the case from being automatically transferred.  Once the case is closed, credits are available and should be processed without waiting for the next financial interaction.

Case closure is considered too late, instead it should be at the point of unlocking the period, if the case type is one which locks the period (DBT is an example of a case type that does not).  Case Types that do not lock the period must wait until closure, there is no other indicator that the case is not a blocker for auto credit transfer.

Unlocking a period within a case will trigger auto credit transfer, but only if:
    Credit transfers are configured for the tax type / return frequency
    At least one of the configuration flags CannotHaveAnAuditCase or CannotHaveARefundCase are set to 1
    The locking reason for the tax return included a Case Type abbreviation for a case type that a flag of 1 refers to

Closing a case will trigger auto credit transfers for all periods within the scope of the case, but only if:
    Credit transfers are configured for the tax type / return frequency
        The configuration flag CannotHaveADebtCase is set to 1, and
        The case type is one that the flag of 1 refers to, i.e. DBT, or

        The configuration flag CannotHaveUnpresentedRefund is set to 1, and
        The case type is one that the flag of 1 refers to, i.e. RFD, and
        The Refund record has no amount left to disburse
developerNotes:
The processing order of cases is not what might be expected.  Consider an Audit case.  Taxpayer Account Changes are made, submitted for approval, approved, and Save and Continue clicked.  At this point the tax return and general ledger tables are updated, penalties recalculated.  Auto credit transfer won't happen, because the case is open and the return is locked.  Once the return is unlocked, it will attempt to process auto credit transfer, but when is the tax return unlocked?

The expectation is that it's at this point, when the changes have been saved.  That turns out not to be the case.  It's not until the case is closed.  The Case is set to Closed, periods within scope are unlocked, the spf_ProcessTaxReturnCaseClosedRules procedure is run.  That's what happens whether the case is closed normally, by optional closure, or by deletion.

Putting the changes in the unlock procedure instead of the case closed procedure makes no difference.  It has been done anyway in case one day unlocking is moved, a decision outside the scope of this change.

New configuration options to allow credit transfers to and from dummy returns

The current logic is for this not to happen, so be sure that cannot be a dummy return is true for source and target to preserver current functionaly.
title: Auto Credit Transfer enhancement - multiple configurable sources - #6 - eligibilty of default assessment / dummy returns

functionalNotes:
Additional functionality in the penalty calculation to handle migrated data that creates situations impossible to duplicate from within RMS.

Enforcement of the fact that a credit transfer out, or a paid out refund (or cancellation of a payment) increases the core tax.
Explanation: credit transfers out and refunds are ultimately sourced from credit returns.  The negative core tax balance decreases in magnitude.  i.e. the core tax balance increases.
developerNotes:
Two new system constants.  DMTransactionMatchingEnabled (defaults to false) and DMTransactionMatchingLimitToSameType (defaults to true).
This is to handle the situation where migrated transactions in a period cancel each other (same effective date, same amount but different sign), but are not excluded because they have no value in ReverseID.  This causes inconsistencies in the penalty calculation.

When set to true, DMTransactionMatchingEnabled looks for these matched migrated transactions and ignores them.  Inconsistency gone.

In Cyprus we have examples of a "(TT51-PAY-A) Transfer from other period)" credit in the suspense account reversed by a "(TT50-PAY) Cancellation of Payment" debit in the cash account.
When DMTransactionMatchingLimitToSameType is left as true, RMS would not match these transactions.  Inconsistency remains.
When DMTransactionMatchingLimitToSameType is set to false, RMS would match these transactions.  Inconsistency gone.

Multiple pre-payments or pre-credit transfers (the latter of which happens regularly when auto credit transfer is configured) were not broken down correctly, the full breakdown was applied to the latest occurrence.
title: CY-1223 - Scenario 2 - Credits without ReverseIDs not being properly handled in debt interest calculations.

functionalNotes: This PR simplifies local debugging of IhoWeb and IhoApi, which previously required enabling IIS and its related modules. By switching to Kestrel with a default ASPNET Core dev certificate, developers can now debug both applications without dealing with tedious IIS setup.
developerNotes:
Description
This PR simplifies local debugging of IhoWeb and IhoApi, which previously required enabling IIS and its related modules. By switching to Kestrel with a default ASPNET Core dev certificate, developers can now debug both applications without dealing with tedious IIS setup.

How to use:
Update IhoWeb and IhoApi to use their .exe startup targets.

Configure Multiple Startup Projects in the solution and set both IhoWeb and IhoApi to start together.

To set a startup project:

Right-click on IhoWeb or IhoApi in Solution Explorer ? Set as Startup Project.

Or, use the dropdown next to the Start Debugging button and select the desired project .exe.

With this setup, any developer can get started quicklyno IIS configuration required. Happy debugging! ??

Note: In production, Kestrel is typically not exposed directly to HTTPS traffic. Instead, it runs behind a reverse proxy (such as Nginx, Apache, or IIS) that handles SSL/TLS termination. This setup is intended solely for local development.

image.png
title: Configure kestrel for local web debugging
